item.title: Episode‌ ‌8:‌ ‌Breaking‌ ‌Elliptic-Curve‌ ‌Signatures‌ ‌With‌ ‌LadderLeak!‌
item.description: LadderLeak is a new attack that exploits side channels present in ECDSA, claiming to allow real-world breaking of ECDSA with less than a bit of nonce leakage. But what does “less than a bit” mean in this context? Is LadderLeak really that effective at breaking ECDSA, with so little information to go on? Joining us this episode are LadderLeak co-authors Akira Takahashi, Mehdi Tibouchi and Yuval Yarom to discuss these questions and more.
item.author: (Nadim Kobeissi)

item.title: Genius is (mostly) comparative - Blog by Amir Bolous
item.description: Some of the best advice I've received has been to turn short-term games into long-term games. In the past, I interpreted this as prioritize actions that further long-term goals over those that generate short-term rewards. After digging a bit deeper and thinking at a different level of abstraction, I now see this piece of advice in a different dimension.

item.title: Additional helpful pseudo-handles: The process token, the thread token, and the effective token | The Old New Thing
item.description: In addition to the pseudo-handles produced by Get­Current­Process() and Get­Current­Thread(), there are also pseudo-handles for tokens. Function Equivalent GetCurrentProcessToken OpenProcessToken(GetCurrentProcess()) GetCurrentThreadToken OpenThreadToken(GetCurrentThread()) GetCurrentThreadEffectiveToken OpenThreadToken(GetCurrentThread()) + OpenProcessToken(GetCurrentProcess()) These pseudo-handles are handy because they can be obtained quickly and don’t need to be closed.
item.author: (Raymond Chen Follow)
